title: Start with Heart
summary: Focus on what you really want for yourself, others, and the relationship before and during the conversation.

details.content: Staying clear about your true motives helps prevent getting sidetracked by emotions or winning at any cost, leading to more productive conversations.
Before discussing a missed deadline with a colleague, remind yourself that your goal is to solve the problem and maintain a good working relationship, not to assign blame.

content: Pause and ask yourself: What do I really want here?
Check your motives if you feel defensive or angry.
Refocus on mutual purpose when the conversation gets tense.

title: Learn to Look
summary: Notice when a conversation becomes crucial and recognize signs of safety problems, such as silence or violence.

details.content: Recognizing when safety is at risk allows you to address it early, preventing misunderstandings and escalation.
You notice your teammate suddenly goes quiet or becomes sarcastic during a discussion, signaling discomfort or defensiveness.

content: Watch for physical and emotional cues in yourself and others.
Identify signs of silence (withdrawing, avoiding) or violence (attacking, controlling).
Pause the conversation to address safety concerns if needed.

title: Make it Safe
summary: Restore safety in the conversation by establishing mutual purpose and mutual respect.

details.content: People only share honestly when they feel safe; restoring safety helps everyone contribute to the dialogue.
If someone feels attacked, you clarify that your intention is to solve the problem together, not to criticize them personally.

content: Apologize sincerely if you’ve hurt someone.
Contrast to clarify your intent (e.g., 'I don’t mean to suggest you’re not committed.').
Find and state a mutual purpose.

title: Master My Stories
summary: Take control of your emotions by examining the stories you tell yourself about others’ actions.

details.content: Our interpretations drive our emotions and reactions; challenging unhelpful stories leads to better outcomes.
Instead of assuming a colleague missed a deadline out of laziness, consider other explanations, like workload or miscommunication.

content: Notice your emotional reactions and the stories behind them.
Ask yourself: What evidence do I have for this story?
Consider alternative explanations for others’ behavior.

title: STATE My Path
summary: Share your views honestly and respectfully using the STATE skills: Share facts, Tell your story, Ask for others’ paths, Talk tentatively, Encourage testing.

details.content: Clear, respectful communication helps you express your perspective without triggering defensiveness.
You say, 'I noticed the report was late (fact). I’m concerned it might affect our project timeline (story). What happened from your perspective?'

content: Start with facts, not judgments.
Share your interpretation, but be open to being wrong.
Invite others to share their views.
Speak tentatively, not dogmatically.
Encourage dialogue and testing of ideas.

title: Explore Others' Paths
summary: Actively seek to understand others’ perspectives and encourage them to share their thoughts and feelings.

details.content: Understanding others’ views builds trust and leads to better solutions.
You ask, 'Can you help me understand what led to your decision?' and listen without interrupting.

content: Ask open-ended questions.
Listen actively and reflect back what you hear.
Show genuine curiosity about others’ experiences.
Acknowledge their feelings and perspectives.

title: Move to Action
summary: Turn the conversation into results by deciding how to take action and following up on commitments.

details.content: Conversations that end without clear decisions or follow-up often lead to frustration and unresolved issues.
After discussing a recurring issue, you agree on specific steps each person will take and set a time to check in.

content: Decide who will do what by when.
Document agreements and next steps.
Follow up to ensure accountability.
Clarify how decisions will be made (consensus, authority, etc.).
